page.title: 11Earlswood Lakes
page.content: Earlswood Lakes were completed in 1823.They were built as a feeder for the Stratford on Avon canal. The locks were being used frequently. At this time Stratford needed to buy water from Worcester and Birmingham canal.So they decided to build their own Reservoir. Earlswood Lakes consists of three lakes: Windmill Lake which is 40 acres, Engine Lake which is 30 acres, and the Nature Preserve which is 15 acres.The Lakes contain 14000 lockfulls of water so it is possible, in theory, for 14 000 barges to pass through the Stratford on Avon canal before needing to buy water. The water was pumped by a steam beam engine which was replaced in the 1930's by an electric pump. 2000 lockfulls can be used by gravity. Today the lakes are used purely for leisure such as boating, fishing and birdwatching.
